Well, some advice that I try and follow myself.
Try and make yourself available and be friendly to journalists.
They do have tight deadlines.
The chances are if they've called you on the telephone, they're probably working to a deadline that afternoon and they really need to talk to you.
They may send you an email if they've got a bit more time, but if they're calling you and and you say, well, I'm sorry, you know I'm with this student.
Call me next week.
They'll probably never talk to you again.
If you try and make yourself available in your friendly to them, then they'll come back to you.
From experience this this is what happens to me now.
They call me up if they want me to give them a quote about someone else is work, and indeed every six months and you scientist journalist, just calls me up to ask me what's going on.
Do I know of anything interesting happening?
Also provide general information on websites these journalists don't have time, you've gotta.
They're not crazy.

Try and provide your biography in an easy to read format.
They don't need to know how many students you supervised to completion or how many papers you published.
They need in a slightly more general things.
So have a kind of general biography available.
Have summaries of your research and easy to understand language.
OK, if you have done some important new research that people may be interested in, provide pointers to it.
